issue.title: Replace OQS_PORTABLE_BUILD and OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS
issue.body:
Following the discussion in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/discussions/943, this replaces OQS_PORTABLE_BUILD and OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS with more flexible (and less confusing) alternatives.

* OQS_DIST_BUILD (default: OFF): "Build distributable library with optimized code for several CPU microarchitectures. Enables run-time CPU feature detection."
* OQS_OPT_TARGET (default: "auto"): "The target microarchitecture for optimization."

OQS_DIST_BUILD is a drop in replacement for the previous OQS_PORTABLE_BUILD. A library built with OQS_DIST_BUILD will include implementations for several microarchitectures, and it will dispatch calls to the correct implementation based the CPU features that are available at run time. The OQS_DIST_BUILD option is refined to one of OQS_DIST_X86_64_BUILD, OQS_DIST_ARM64v8_BUILD, or OQS_DIST_ARM32v7_BUILD at compile time depending on CMAKE_SYSTEM_PROCESSOR. This is useful for cross compiling and it also simplifies some logic throughout the build.

OQS_OPT_TARGET can take a value of "auto", "generic", or the name of a CPU like "haswell". When OQS_DIST_BUILD=ON we force OQS_OPT_TARGET=generic.

On x86_64, "generic" means we'll compile with "-march=x86-64". On ARM64v8 "generic" means "-mcpu=cortex-a53". On ARM32v7 "generic" means "-mcpu=cortex-a5". This is like OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS=OFF.

On any architecture, "auto" will try to determine the current CPU using "march=native" (if it's supported). This is like the previous OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS=ON

Downstream builds that set OQS_PORTABLE_BUILD or OQS_USE_CPU_FEATURES will fail. So we should prepare for that if we decide to make these changes.

*edit*: Removing OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS had the side effect that our ARM jobs tried to execute detect_gcc_clang_intrinsics.c. I took the opportunity to add both compile-time detection of ARM crypto features and neon. It is now possible to cross compile for ARM and optimize for the target CPU (relevant to #775). I also took the opportunity to add run-time detection of ARM features, and I replaced OQS_get_available_CPU_extensions (01efe50) for efficiency reasons (previous implementation was copying ~40 bytes on return).

comment.body: `OQS_DIST_BUILD (default: OFF)` — this is a change from the previously-default-on `OQS_PORTABLE_BUILD` right?

issue.title: Replace OQS_PORTABLE_BUILD and OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS
issue.body:
Following the discussion in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/discussions/943, this replaces OQS_PORTABLE_BUILD and OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS with more flexible (and less confusing) alternatives.

* OQS_DIST_BUILD (default: OFF): "Build distributable library with optimized code for several CPU microarchitectures. Enables run-time CPU feature detection."
* OQS_OPT_TARGET (default: "auto"): "The target microarchitecture for optimization."

OQS_DIST_BUILD is a drop in replacement for the previous OQS_PORTABLE_BUILD. A library built with OQS_DIST_BUILD will include implementations for several microarchitectures, and it will dispatch calls to the correct implementation based the CPU features that are available at run time. The OQS_DIST_BUILD option is refined to one of OQS_DIST_X86_64_BUILD, OQS_DIST_ARM64v8_BUILD, or OQS_DIST_ARM32v7_BUILD at compile time depending on CMAKE_SYSTEM_PROCESSOR. This is useful for cross compiling and it also simplifies some logic throughout the build.

OQS_OPT_TARGET can take a value of "auto", "generic", or the name of a CPU like "haswell". When OQS_DIST_BUILD=ON we force OQS_OPT_TARGET=generic.

On x86_64, "generic" means we'll compile with "-march=x86-64". On ARM64v8 "generic" means "-mcpu=cortex-a53". On ARM32v7 "generic" means "-mcpu=cortex-a5". This is like OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS=OFF.

Downstream builds that set OQS_PORTABLE_BUILD or OQS_USE_CPU_FEATURES will fail. So we should prepare for that if we decide to make these changes.

*edit*: Removing OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS had the side effect that our ARM jobs tried to execute detect_gcc_clang_intrinsics.c. I took the opportunity to add both compile-time detection of ARM crypto features and neon. It is now possible to cross compile for ARM and optimize for the target CPU (relevant to #775). I also took the opportunity to add run-time detection of ARM features, and I replaced OQS_get_available_CPU_extensions (01efe50) for efficiency reasons (previous implementation was copying ~40 bytes on return).

issue.title: Rework visualisation logic

- Remove code that's basically copied -> more parameterization
- Add support for selecting/differentiation between (many) different architectures
- Merge JSON files for different test types/configurations and running on different architectures into single JSON files

comment.body: @dstebila Don't mind the question above: I now decided :-) Please take another look at https://test.openquantumsafe.org/visv3/index.html

issue.title: Graceful runtime CPU feature handling

labels.name: future-work
labels.description: Will not be fixed in current release cycle

issue.body:
Ensure all code is designed such that it can not only be configured at compile time to deal with different CPU feature sets (e.g., presence/absence of AVX2) but also handle those gracefully at runtime, e.g, by automatically falling back to a non-optimised version of the same functionality.

In other words, all code compiled with, e.g., `-mavx2` should also run without error on CPUs that do *not* have support for all features (AVX2 in this example).

To help with this, we will integrate the [CPU features](https://github.com/google/cpu_features) library and for starters will add warnings if the library is running on a CPU with a feature set different from the one encountered during build (reducing the surprise when one encounters an `illegal instruction exception` during execution until this issue is fully addressed :-)

Edited by @dstebila to add:

- [X] Use cpu\_features instead of \_\_builtin\_cpu
- [X] Update copy-from-pqclean schemes to do runtime detection
- [ ] Runtime detection for SHA-3 ~using  [XKCP](https://github.com/XKCP/XKCP)~
- [X] Runtime detection for Frodo (#878)
- [ ] Runtime detection for SIKE
- [ ] Runtime detection for BIKE
~- [ ] Runtime detection for qTesla~
- [ ] Runtime detection for Picnic
- [x] Runtime detection for AES

comment.body: Would suggest to check off SHA3 when #957 lands. OK, @jschanck?

issue.title: How to change the supported algorithm and use self-defined algorithm
issue.body: I saw in some blogs that you can change algorithm with engine and mark the changed algorithm in RSA_mothod, DSA_method etc. If I want to change signature algorithm in this case, what should I do? What's the relation between RSA and dilithium for example?

comment.body: Closing due to inactivity. Please re-open if the issue persists (and provide further input as per the questions above).

issue.title: enable liboqs-tagged builds
issue.body:
By default, demos are always built using the current upstream masters.
For interoperability and regression testing, specific builds tagged to a liboqs release tag and all corresponding downstream package versions are sensible additional build options. This feature can then also be used to automate generating liboqs-version-tagged docker images for all applications and thus, improve (reduce) release-cycle build time over the complete OQS SW stack.

Challenge is that (tag-)conditional Dockerfiles make builds un-cacheable.
Additional challenge is that such logic would have to be copied into each Dockerfile as there seems to be no `#include` logic in Dockerfiles.
Another challenge is that more parameters than just tags need to be considered (other upstream options change over time, e.g. OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS came and went away).

Maybe just keeping liboqs-version-tagged Dockerfiles is sufficient?

comment.body: Opting for local Dockerfiles. Closing as that solves the issue for me.

issue.title: Re-activate OSX docker building when supported by CircleCI

labels.name: future work
labels.description: This issue is something that may be dealt with

issue.body: As of now (Mar 2020) CircleCI does not support building current OSX docker images, so CCI config needs to be updated if that capability is available again.

comment.body: Don't see particular value in this issue any more. If OSX-based demos building doesn't work for some user, we can re-open.

comment.body: Alternatively, I'd be open to changing the default value of OQS_DIST_BUILD.

issue.title: SIGILL in SIDH code
issue.body:
I'm having trouble reproducing this locally, but on Github Actions for `liboqs-rust` I'm getting SIGILL in SIDH consistently.

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-rust/runs/2276909119#step:12:62

```
test kem::SidhP434::test_encaps_decaps ... error: test failed, to rerun pass '-p oqs --lib'

Caused by:
  process didn't exit successfully: `/home/runner/work/liboqs-rust/liboqs-rust/target/debug/deps/oqs-c655d61dbe5addf1 --test-threads 1` (signal: 4, SIGILL: illegal instruction)
```

For debugging purposes, I already pulled out the support CPU flags on Github Actions:

```
 flags		: fpu vme de pse tsc msr pae mce cx8 apic sep mtrr pge mca cmov pat pse36 clflush mmx fxsr sse 
sse2 ss ht syscall nx pdpe1gb rdtscp lm constant_tsc rep_good nopl xtopology cpuid pni pclmulqdq ssse3 fma cx16 
pcid sse4_1 sse4_2 movbe popcnt aes xsave avx f16c rdrand hypervisor lahf_lm abm invpcid_single pti fsgsbase bmi1 
avx2 smep bmi2 erms invpcid xsaveopt md_clear
```

The difference with my local set of `flags`:

* My computer doesn't have `hypervisor`
* GHA don't have `{'ida', 'flush_l1d', 'tsc_adjust', 'hwp_epp', 'vpid', 'ibpb', 'bts', 'tm', 'xsaves', 'ssbd', 'acpi', 'dtes64', 'dts', 'vmx', 'hwp_notify', 'pts', 'stibp', 'x2apic', 'intel_pt', 'xsavec', 'tpr_shadow', 'xgetbv1', 'ept', 'hwp_act_window', 'rdseed', 'hwp', 'adx', 'tsc_deadline_timer', 'sdbg', 'smap', 'tm2', 'est', 'ibrs', 'arat', 'aperfmperf', 'pebs', 'dtherm', 'ept_ad', 'clflushopt', 'mpx', 'epb', 'pdcm', 'nonstop_tsc', 'monitor', 'cpuid_fault', 'xtpr', '3dnowprefetch', 'pln', 'art', 'arch_perfmon', 'vnmi', 'pbe', 'ds_cpl', 'flexpriority'}`

comment.body: It's adx. SIKE's CMakeLists assumes that "BMI2" implies presence of both `mulx` and `adox` instructions. But there are Nahalem processors, like that GitHub actions Ivy Bridge machine, with `mulx` but not `adox`.

issue.title: Update RELEASE notes with new build flags [skip ci]

comment.body:
> Alternatively, I'd be open to changing the default value of OQS_DIST_BUILD.

I don't mind either way: Doesn't highlighting the new flags in the release notes make sense regardless? Personally I think the way it is now is "the norm": Build on and for a given platform (only). Portability/Distributability is a good feature to have but does it have to be default? It also significantly slows down some algorithms (that fall back to reference code w/o CPU feature detection code).

issue.title: Fix missing parameter needed at least on android
issue.body:
As mentioned in #11 no matter of how the jni is integrated for android it fails as `local referenced is deleted` or something.  
After debugging it on my android device i found out that for innerclasses the superclass must be passed as well.   
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/25363027/jni-getmethodid-not-working-for-constructor-of-inner-class
I dont have a clue why it is working on common jvms for linux or windows but it crashes on android.  
I tested the fix locally on my android device and with ci in github for x86_64 and arm64: 
 https://github.com/Hatzen/LibOQSTestApp/runs/2249616782   
  
I didnt test it yet for previous working common jvms. But i hope circle ci can do this at this point?

comment.body:
Good point, thanks for advice.  
I just ported the SigTest.java to android and tried running it (additionally i found out my tests didnt worked correctly yet..) i had to fix an other issue with not finding java.lang.Long class for some reason. java.lang.object a few lines above seems to work for some reason..   
Changes made regarding to: https://github.com/Hatzen/LibOQSTestApp/commit/0fe8541ffd457aeb2f7bc9ace1f3fdd88930ddf7
